title: How much of the U.S. corn crop will be planted as of 31 May 2020, according to the USDA?

88% as of 5/26. Would be unprecedented over past few decades if we did not reach 90% in the next week.
Now at 88% with one more week.

Over last 40 years, there are no cases in which a week 21 value of ≥ 83% did not result in a week 22 value of  ≥90%. Given that we're working with 88% in today's report, and there is some decent weather in subject region to round out the subject timeframe, I feel confident at 100%.

Today's planting report is out [1] and is at 88%, falling slightly behind the industry estimate of 90% [2]. The question now is, will the last 2% be planted in the next week. The states heavily lagging include NY, PA and ND. ND looks quite clear weather-wise, though NY & PA look like they have 2-3 days of rain coming in the next week (Google weather search for major cities in up-state NY and PA; Fargo for ND).  The ability to hit 90% looks positive so, I am going to hold steady on my current estimate. [1] https://www.nass.usda.gov/Charts_and_Maps/Crop_Progress_&_Condition/2020/US_2020.pdf
[2] https://www.agriculture.com/news/crops/88-of-the-us-corn-crop-is-seeded-below-expectations-usda-reports

As of 17 May 2020, 18 states have completed 92% of the planting with only the hardest acres available in the remaining states. Particularly, in the Dakotas, there are still standing crops.
Hence, it is highly likely that the planting will reach a target of more than 90%.
Already past 80%, With 10 days to go. Weather should be dry enough in major states where planting is mostly 90% already.
I am changing the prediction because of May 18, 2020: Crop Progress updates!! https://downloads.usda.library.cornell.edu/usda-esmis/files/8336h188j/kd17dd70q/gm80jg11q/prog2120.pdf

Planting continues to run far ahead of the 5-year average [1], at about 80% for mid-May, with a few states almost wrapped up, at above 90% [2]. There are a couple states that are running quite far behind (ND, PA) [2], but they appear to have less area dedicated to corn than those running near or above 90% [3]. Adjusting to put more in the 90%+ bin. [1] https://www.nass.usda.gov/Charts_and_Maps/Crop_Progress_&_Condition/2020/US_2020.pdf

As on 12 May 2020, as per USDA survey, already 67% of the estimated crop is planted. With the same pattern of the impact of corona, the corn planting trend may not be affected in the next 3 weeks. With all other conditions such as steady availability of inputs, futures price of corn ( it appears to be bearish) and shorter time to make an alternate decision to switch crops, it is highly likely that the USDA estimates will be reached by 31 May.  
The USDA data also shows most of the 19 states have shown higher planted area than that in 2019 for the same time last year.
The weather forecast is also favorable so that plantings are not delayed.
67%. Still ahead of schedule but this is a slower rise than expected.

67% reported today, just a smidge below the last-40-years median of 69%. Given we were pretty far ahead last week, it was lower than I expected this week, so I'm hedging a tiny bit, given that there have been 2 years [1] higher than 67% at this point that fell just short of 90% (1990 and 1982, 69%-88% and 69%-89% respectively). That said, there have been 14 of 40 years that were lower than 67% at this point that still managed to get to 96% by the last week, so far more evidence that we're on track/can catch up if needed than otherwise. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1884960899

https://www.agriculture.com/video/corn-planting-surges-ahead-with-dry-weather

In a typical year they make 90% or more. Have been on lower end due to potential weather problems and coronavirus. It appears planting overall is going well but those storms coming through midwest recently give me pause. Report out on May 11 should be helpful.
Ok 51% today. That is an addition of 20% in just a few days.

Revising for latest report - 51% planted vs. 5-year average of 39%.

Based on the latest data from the USDA [1], this year's crop is running well ahead of the 5-year trend. Updating forecast to shift more weight to 90% percent. There are reports that all the corn in Iowa will be in the ground by next week, due to good soil conditions [2]. Ohio is running behind the 5 year average, though ahead of last year [3]. MN is running well ahead of last year due to good weather and 2 weeks ahead of the 5 year average [4]. 
With the high-level numbers running well-ahead, and good local results from a few samples, changing my forecast to be more heavily on 90%. [1] https://www.nass.usda.gov/Charts_and_Maps/Crop_Progress_&_Condition/2020/US_2020.pdf

Hattip @dglid for analysis and explanation of the process for setting planting statistics. It helped me see more clearly the key points. I'm not quite all in for 100% yet, however. There are 4 long weeks for the question to run and weather could change, etc.

This question seems ripe for boosting my accuracy score but to be a team player, here goes... In the last 40 years [1], here's how many years have fell into each bin (i.e. base rates - see my spreadsheet with graphs, etc here [2]):
<70%: 1 (2%)
70-80%: 1 (2%)
80-90%: 4 (10%)
90%+: 34 (85%) So, 85% for bin 4 seems like a reasonable starting point, already more than double the crowd forecast.  2019 should definitely not be used as a baseline. It is the only year in the last 20 years to not reach 90%+ by Week 22, the week in question. It is the only year in the last 40 years to not reach 70%+ by Week 22. This paper went as far to call 2019 a "black swan event" given the historically wet season. [3] 2020 is at 27% in Week 17, above all years at the same point that ended at <90%. It's also above the average (21%) and median (24%). It's worth noting that there are many years where planting lagged even further behind the ones that ended at <90%, so good evidence for being able to catch up even if you fall behind. Cursory review of Google News items related to "corn planting" [4] indicate no concern out of the normal. Overall, sentiment appears normal if not positive for weather in the month of May. Re: @bobrown and other's concern about ethanol prices leading to reduced demand, my reading of the survey methodology used in the resolution reports for this question (example at bottom of latest report [5]) is that farmers are surveyed on how much of their corn they've planted _of which they are planning to plant_. So, even if COVID-19 concerns do affect the _quantities_ of corn they intend to plant, it _should not negatively affect_ the responses to the survey as to their progress in planting the crops they intend to plant. The only thing that would seem to negatively affect the progress are weather and potentially labor, although I'm not even sure if that's a concern. Additionally, cursory review of articles online suggest that farmers likely needed to make a decision to plant a different crop some time back, and even if they did, they simply wouldn't be included in the denominator for the data in the survey. All of the above leads me to be confident in putting 100% in bin 4, >90% planted as of May 31st. [1] https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/91DD05A9-29E6-3338-B1E7-342500C9F68D
[2] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1884960899
[3] https://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2019/06/another-look-at-late-planting-of-the-2019-corn-crop.html
[4] https://www.google.com/search?q=corn+planting&tbm=nws
[5] https://downloads.usda.library.cornell.edu/usda-esmis/files/8336h188j/vd66wk03z/9z903k54h/prog1820.pdf

53% The April 27th result was 27%.  This is perfectly in line with the 2014-2018 average for this date. If it were to continue at the same pace the total for 1 June would be 96%.  However, it is still early. Several factors may prevent the typical growth rate such as bad weather. Both North Dakota and Pennsylvania have not stared planting yet. This is is unusual and may hinder average rates. The next progress report should result in a growth rate of between 17 and 22 percentage points (44%-49% total) to maintain the 'above 90%' pace by the 1st of June.

Current data shows most state are behind average (https://www.agriculture.com/crops/progress-maps/corn-planting-progress) and the total as of Monday, April 20th is 7%, which is a few percentage points behind the 5 years average (https://www.agriculture.com/news/crops/us-corn-7-planted-soybeans-2-usda-says). Though behind the 5-year trend, it appears to be ahead of the 2019 trend (https://www.nass.usda.gov/Charts_and_Maps/Crop_Progress_&_Condition/2020/US_2020.pdf), with the 2019 trend being far behind the average. The 5-year average is at 90% on May 31st, making 2019 look like a strong outlier. COVID, of course, adds further complications that could impact planting.

June 10 - 99% | 83% ||   +3% | +13% 2019 was a very bad year for Farmers. I believe this was primarily due to weather. According to to NOAA’s national center for environmental Information, the 12 months preceding May 2019 were the ‘wettest on record’.      The increase at the end of May was due to some farmers facing deadlines to plant their crop to still be covered by federally backed insurance policies. [1] The Prospective Plantings report provides the first official estimates of US farmers' 2020 planting intentions [2]. The report forecasts a 7.3% increase in intended crop plantings from 2019. It also projected 3 million acres of prevented planting, down from 19.6 million last year.  For the most part, the report suggests that more corn will be planted. It does not indicate when it will be planted.  COVID-19 may affect the levels and timing of corn being planted. It might be difficult to hire seasonal workers to help plant crops during May  At this stage the data suggests that the 2020 schedule will be closer to the average, not 2019. However, caution needs to be taken due to COVID-19 and volatile weather.  Criticism is very welcome! From what I can see, planting is going well so far. There are pockets of dry area's and no doubt some Covid lockdowns in places will slow down planting temporarily but it is not universal.  
Last years crop was down so many farmers will be hoping for higher yields in 2020. The corn that was left over from 2019 is reportably sub standard so I would assume removed by now in order for new crops. 
As many forecasters point out the planted % long term average is typically 90%+ by May 31. 
There are no price or weather indicators that seem to be making farmers hesitate from planting at present. I did not look at the weather situation for all 18 states individually so a general comment. There was a valid comment in relation to less ethanol demand but I could not find any anecdotal comments that it was making farmers pause planting.   My answer is mainly governed by the long term average and lack of trade or weather events to date that would detract significantly from the long term average.

The weather forecast is expected to be warmer-than-average for spring, indicating more activity in early spring months (https://weather.com/forecast/national/news/2020-02-12-spring-2020-march-april-may-temperature-outlook). Using Missouri as a guide because its plantings appeared to be in line with the averages (https://downloads.usda.library.cornell.edu/usda-esmis/files/8336h188j/wd3766076/j6731d80p/prog2319.pdf), historical records show that typically more than 90% is planted by the end of May (https://www.nass.usda.gov/Charts_and_Maps/Crop_Progress_&_Condition/2018/MO_2018.pdf). Understanding that flooding and some economics played a role in last years reduction (https://www.fb.org/market-intel/crop-planting-delays-reach-historic-levels-resulting-in-high-levels-of-unce), I am optimistic considering that flooding likely won't be as impactful where corn is grown (https://www.agweb.com/article/moderate-major-flooding-expected-23-states) and corn is on the up after new trade deals with China (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/13/reuters-america-grains-soy-declines-corn-firms-as-u-s-china-deal-terms-awaited.html).

Northeast Arkansas, and the weather and international trade strife that have plagued the sector in recent years remains eerily similar in 2020. The trade war with China still hasn’t been resolved, and the winter weather pattern of intermittent rains with little or no drying periods, continues to challenge producers.
When it comes to deciding between planting rice, soybean or other crops in 2020, it’s not just a question of markets and futures contracts. For many growers, it’s a question of when the ground will be dry enough to work, “If you see yourself a field ready for planting right now, chances are, that happened last summer.” - Rice agronomist Jarrod Hardke.

Yes snow pack is less but potential foe excess rain in some areas and drought in ithers possible if not likely. Some adjustment but sticking with this.

Rather than resort to the weather, I'm going to view this as a Markov process where the most recent observations are by far the most important. We'll call the week of 5/31 as the 22nd week of the year. Here are the numbers for weeks 21 and 22 since 2014: 2014: 73, 88
2015: 85, 92
2016: 86, 94
2017: 84, 91
2018: 81, 92
2019: 49, 58 In other words, 2019 was an unusual season. I stress SEASON because by July 1st corn production was back up to the 90th percentile. So, I'm going to say there is a 10% chance we have a season like 2019. Most likely we'll be in the high 80s or low 90s, and because of last year, I'll put a little more weight on the 80s, but 90s really are the most likely outcome. This is a question that we should all be able to get fairly accurately right before the due date.
Weather uncertainties, spring flooding, and ongoing issues with trade, particularly with China will make farmers hesitate to plant as soon as the conditions are feasible.
Some of my peers are rightfully pointing out heavy moisture. Would like to point out above average temperatures and less snow at higher latitudes meaning easier planting if drainage picks up.
Increase in tech and global warming should lead to a slow steady trend towards early seeding.  But this isn't the type of thing that changes quickly.  slightly up from 67%
I’m assuming at least 1/3rd will be left to plant due to weather

I don't have a structured way to use this information, so I'm just going to affirm my prior forecast and drop this link here: https://www.isciences.com/blog/2020/02/14/isciences-worldwide-water-watch-list-february-2020 This gets you to the latest edition of IScience's Worldwide Water Watchlist, which forecasts water anomalies around the world, including in the U.S., nine months out. The latest says this: United States: The forecast through April indicates widespread water surpluses in the Northern Plains States and Upper Midwest, exceptional in the Dakotas and Nebraska. Moderate surpluses are expected in Tennessee, the Carolinas, Mississippi, Alabama, and Georgia. Areas of deficit include central Colorado, eastern Texas, and northern California.
2019 was an exceptionally wet and rainy year. Much more likely (providing for a more normal rainfall) we will see a 75 to 90 percent completion

I see a saturated Lower Mississippi valley. The Central Plains and Mid West are perma frost right now storing up moisture at the surface, promising a soggy thaw. However new gear in the fields like rubber trak tricycle gear to float across those wet fields has improved things a lot the last decade.
Hattip to @ulfelder for an excelent rationale and set of numbers. Mean reversion is also a good saw to lean on.
May31 is very late and farmers would usually plant soy instead when forced this late. The caveat relates to northern tier areas where soy is a poor fit due to day length and cool weather generally.

REVISION TO EARLIER REVISION. Third time's the charm, right? I eyeballed the data from previous years and saw that June 1 was sometimes around the 8th report and sometimes the 9th. So I went back through the scraped data and the online archive by hand to pluck out the values for the report closest to June 1 and interpolated in a few cases where June 1 was right in between two reports. So: probabilities derived from 1,000 simulations of a Weibull distribution with shape (20.4) and scale (95.7) estimated from reported values from approximately June 1 for the years 1995 to 2019. Chose Weibull after exploring a few options via the 'fitdistrplus' package in R. Fit is not perfect, but good enough, I think. The simulations imply ~0 chance of < 70%, but I don't like posting zeros, so I borrowed 1 percentage point from [> 80%, < 90%] for it. So this is purely an outside view for now, with no attempt to adjust for long-term weather forecasts or any other season-specific chatter for 2020. My plan is to stick with this forecast until we start getting observations for this year, at which point I'm hoping to see if I can get some bang for the buck from a multivariate approach that incorporates information about the season to date. Major options would seem to be survival analysis (expected time to 100%) with time-varying covariates or an ML implementation of something similar. I've scraped the available historical data from the USDA library site from 2011 onward to prepare for that process but haven't tried any modeling yet.

REVISION TO EARLIER ESTIMATES after I realized that the report on which the question will be resolved this year will be the 9th of the season, not the 8th, per the USDA release calendar. A week can make a big difference on this one, it seems. So: probabilities derived from 1,000 simulations of a Weibull distribution with shape (24.4) and scale (97.6) estimated from reported values for week 9 (approx. early June) of the reporting period from the years 1995 to 2019. Chose Weibull after exploring a few options via the 'fitdistrplus' package in R. Fit is not perfect, but good enough, I think. The simulations imply 0 chance of < 70%, but I don't like posting zeros, so I borrowed 1 percentage point from [> 80%, < 90%] for it. So this is purely an outside view for now, with no attempt to adjust for long-term weather forecasts or any other season-specific chatter for 2020. My plan is to stick with this forecast until we start getting observations for this year, at which point I'm hoping to see if I can get some bang for the buck from a multivariate approach that incorporates information about the season to date. Major options would seem to be survival analysis (expected time to 100%) with time-varying covariates or an ML implementation of something similar. I've scraped the available historical data from the USDA library site from 2011 onward to prepare for that process but haven't tried any modeling yet.

“The USDA's most recent weekly Crop Progress report indicated that only 23 percent of the corn acreage in 18 major producing states was planted as of May 5, compared to a five-year average of 46 percent.May 9, 2019”

Probabilities derived from 1,000 simulations of a Weibull distribution with shape (13.5) and scale (92.4) estimated from reported values for week 8 (approx. end of May/start of June) of the reporting period from the years 1995 to 2019. (N.B. Did not bootstrap to address uncertainty in those estimates.) Chose Weibull after exploring a few options via the 'fitdistrplus' package in R. So this is purely an outside view for now, with no attempt to adjust for long-term weather forecasts or any other season-specific chatter for 2020. My plan is to stick with this forecast until we start getting observations for this year, at which point I'm hoping to see if I can get some bang for the buck from a multivariate approach that incorporates information about the season to date. Major options would seem to be survival analysis (expected time to 100%) with time-varying covariates or an ML implementation of something similar. I've scraped the available historical data from the USDA library site to prepare for that process but haven't tried any modeling yet.
